title: 106_s3148
content: The "Access to Books for Children Act" or the "ABC Act" amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to provide better access to books and reading materials for children, including opportunities to own books through an inexpensive book distribution program for reading motivation. The Secretary is authorized to contract with Reading is Fundamental (RIF) to support programs promoting reading motivation by distributing inexpensive books to children. The contract requires RIF to subcontract with local groups to establish and operate reading programs for children from birth through secondary school age. The contractor must ensure that funds are used to pay for family literacy programs serving school-age children with special needs, prioritizing low-income, at-risk, disabled, foster, homeless, migrant, library-deprived, institutionalized, and incarcerated children. The contractor must provide technical assistance to subcontractors, report annually to the Secretary on funded programs, and adhere to additional terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. The Secretary will not make payments for book acquisition and distribution unless certain conditions are met. The contractor or subcontractor must obtain books at favorable discounts, with the Federal share covering 75% of costs (100% for certain programs). $25,000,000 is authorized for this section. Authorized to be appropriated $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 and necessary sums for the following four years. "Authorized to be appropriated $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2001 and necessary sums for the following four years. Local partnerships for books." The Secretary is authorized to contract with a national organization to support programs distributing new books to disadvantaged children and families through tutoring and mentoring. The contract must provide technical support and resources to local partnerships to enhance reading motivation for at-risk children. The contract with a national organization supports local partnerships to provide new books to disadvantaged children in tutoring and mentoring programs. Funds are allocated to subcontractors for program costs, with priority given to those serving economically disadvantaged families and those without library access. Annual reports on book distribution and partnership support are required. The Secretary ensures favorable discounts for new books purchased under the program, equivalent to those given by publishers in similar circumstances without Federal assistance. The term 'Federal share' refers to the cost covered by the government. The Federal share for purchasing books is 50% of the cost to the contractor, except for programs serving children of migrant or seasonal farmworkers where it is 100%. Contractors must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 50% of the amount received. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001, with additional appropriations for the following years. "Partnerships for Infants and Young Children are established under SEC. 10521." The Secretary is authorized to contract with a national organization to support programs distributing free books to children under 5 and promoting reading readiness skills. Subcontracts with local groups or agencies are required under the contract. The subcontractor will establish and operate reading motivation programs for children aged birth to 5 years, with a focus on children with special needs. Funds will be used for the Federal share of program costs. Priority will be given to programs serving low-income children, children with disabilities, and foster children. The contractor will provide technical assistance to subcontractors and report annually on the effectiveness of national and local programs funded under this section, including those for children with disabilities, foster children, homeless children, migrant children, children without library access, children without adequate medical insurance, and children enrolled in a State Medicaid program. The Secretary will only make payments for book acquisition and distribution under the contract if the contractor ensures favorable discounts from publishers or distributors. The Federal share covers 50% of the subcontractor's book purchasing costs. The Federal share for programs serving children of migrant or seasonal farmworkers is 100 percent of costs to the subcontractor. The contractor must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 50 percent of the amount received. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001, with additional appropriations for the following years. The Secretary will annually evaluate programs under this part to assess their effectiveness in meeting goals. $500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001, with additional funding for the following years.
